oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Erosion in Fayette County, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Log cabin with side chimney sits atop a hill. It is surrounded by massive hillside erosion.

Drought continued to be a problem in the South throughout the 1930s. Farmers had overproduced crops to the detriment of the soil (and prices), and erosion affected farmers' production ability. Consequently, many farms were foreclosed on during the Great Depression. The FDR administration first attempted to alleviate farm troubles through the Agricultural Adjustment Act, but the Supreme Court nixed it. Congress replaced it with farm-lending programs and instruction in soil conservation methods.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Farms; Erosion; Soil Conservation; Conservation of Natural Resources
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee Department of Conservation
